text.p: The turnout in Bosnia's first post-war elections was between 60 and 70 per cent according to preliminary figures, the head of the international group organising them said on Saturday.
Robert Frowick, mission chief of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), also told a news conference the polls were almost entirely free of abuse.
"That is a very high turnout well beyond what any of us imagined when we began this procedure," Frowick told reporters.
"I would emphasise our satisfaction with the high turnout."

He said that according to preliminary figures an estimated 20,000 Moslems had crossed the ethnic divide to vote in their former homes in the Bosnian Serb republic, while some 4,000 Serbs had crossed in the other direction to vote in Moslem-Croat federation territory.
"The elections were almost entirely free of abuse," Frowick added.
